For me, it would depend on how predictable and simple the generated sql is. If it is generally no more complicated than your example, you can break out the SELECT, FROM, and WHERE clauses (and there aren't aliases for tables or columns). Then you should be able to tokenize the first two on commas and sort them alphabetically.

If the WHERE includes other operators, it will be more difficult to create an expression tree that you can check.

Good luck. 

----- Original Message -----
From: Jeff Nielsen <jeff.nielsen@...>
Date: Sunday, July 20, 2003 7:48 pm
Subject: [junit] Testing SQL select statements for semantic equivalency

> I'd be interested in people's thoughts on the easiest/best way to do
> this.  Basically, we have a bunch of JUnit tests that check SQL
> "SELECT" statements that are generated by a framework.  
> 
> These tests are currently a little painful to maintain, because if you
> modify the framework so that the order of the tables, columns, or 
> whereclause statements changes somehow, every test has to change.  
> That got
> me wondering about how to do an 
> 
>  assertSemanticEquals(expectedSQL, actualSQL)
> 
> where the order of things within each brance of the select is
> irrelevant.  For example,
> 
>  select foo.col1, bar.col2
>      from bar, foo 
>      where bar.id = foo.id and bar.id > 4
>      order by bar.col2
> 
> is semantically equivalent to
> 
>  select bar.col2, foo.col1
>      from foo, bar 
>      where bar.id > 4 and foo.id = bar.id
>      order by bar.col2
> 
> 
> -- 
> Jeff Nielsen
> Digital Focus
> jeff.nielsen@...
> http://www.digitalfocus.com
